docs.lead_paragraph: Three large new studies are challenging the safety and benefits of clot-busting drugs for older people suffering heart attacks, particularly those 75 and older. The drugs fail to benefit many such heart attack patients, and those 75 and older may be at higher risk of death from bleeding, strokes and ruptured hearts, two of the studies found.
docs.abstract: Three large new studies challenge safety and benefits of clot-busting drugs for older people suffering heart attacks, particularly those 75 and older; two of studies find that those 75 and older may be at higher risk of death from bleeding, strokes and ruptured hearts; findings are surprising because of widespread belief that clot-busting drugs help older patients as they clearly do younger ones; about million Americans suffer heart attacks each year, and about one-third of them occur in people 75 and older; journal Circulation, noting studies' results, stresses urgent need to reassess recommendations for treating heart attacks in older people (M)
docs.snippet: Three large new studies are challenging the safety and benefits of clot-busting drugs for older people suffering heart attacks, particularly those 75 and older.    The drugs fail to benefit many such heart attack patients, and those 75 and older may...

docs.lead_paragraph: The sense of smell, as Marcel Proust and his madeleine made clear, is intimately tied to feeling and memory. So it is perhaps not surprising that in schizophrenia, an illness that plays havoc with the emotional capacities of those who suffer from it, the sense of smell is impaired.

headline.main: Emotional Malady Is Linked To Smell

docs.abstract: New study suggests link between schizophrenia and reduced sense of smell; researchers show that people with schizophrenia show deficits in their ability to detect, identify and remember odors; Dr Bruce Turetsky of University of Pennsylvania says smell is tightly linked to emotional processing; says further investigation of relationship between olfaction and schizophrenia may also help shed light on emotional disturbances that are characteristic of the illness (M)
docs.snippet: The sense of smell, as Marcel Proust and his madeleine made clear, is intimately tied to feeling and memory.    So it is perhaps not surprising that in schizophrenia, an illness that plays havoc with the emotional capacities of those who suffer from...

docs.lead_paragraph: Soon, the human genome will be completely mapped allowing doctors to detect, treat and prevent disease on a level unimaginable a few decades ago. But while genetic screening tests are remarkable diagnostic tools, they are not without potential harm to those who happen to carry a deleterious trait. As a physician who routinely orders such tests, I thought I long understood this dynamic. But I needed my wife, Kate, for a more definitive lesson. When Kate told me she was pregnant with our first child I was, of course, elated. Soon enough, I began to worry about the possibility of a less than perfectly healthy baby. Most expectant parents nervously ponder this issue, but my work as a pediatrician creates an especially skewed vision: many of the children who inhabit my world are among that tiny minority with the most serious and often the rarest illnesses. In a strange sense, when abnormality and disease dominate your view, it becomes ''normal.''

headline.main: One Side Effect of Genetic Testing: Fear

docs.abstract: Dr Howard Markel article on his apprehension as expectant father when his pregnant wife tests positive for rare genetic disease; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Addictive and compulsive disorders are notoriously difficult to treat, particularly when they involve a substance or behavior that, when used or practiced normally, is an essential or important part of life, like eating or sex. When people lose control of such behaviors, the goal of treatment is not to cut them out completely, as might be done with alcohol or nicotine, but to re-establish a healthier pattern of use. This is certainly the case for a recently recognized, fast-growing form of out-of-control sexual activity known as cybersex addiction or compulsivity in which people may spend dozens of hours a week online viewing sites that cater to sexual titillation and satisfaction. In treating cybersex addiction, the aim is not to deprive those afflicted of access to computers or sexual outlets but to prevent their abuse.

headline.main: First Step Is Recognizing the Signs of Internet Abuse

docs.abstract: Personal Health column on recently recognized, fast-growing form of out-of-control sexual activity known as cybersex addiction, in which people spend many hours online, viewing sites that cater to sexual titillation and satisfiction; in treating this addiction, aim is not to deprive those afflicted of access to computers or sexual outlets but to prevent their abuse; Dr Jennifer Schneider, author of book on sexual addiction, speaks about treating cybersex abuse; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sex is the hottest topic among adult users of the Internet, with studies showing that fully a third of all visits directed to sexually oriented Web sites, chat rooms and news groups. For most people these forays into cybersex are relatively harmless pursuits, but experts in the field say that the affordability, accessibility and anonymity of the Internet are fueling a brand new psychological disorder -- cybersex addiction -- that appears to be spreading with astonishing rapidity and bringing turmoil to the lives of those affected.

headline.main: Cybersex Gives Birth to a Psychological Disorder

docs.abstract: Experts in field say affordability, accessibility and anonymity of Internet are fueling brand new psychological disorder--cybersex addiction--that appears to be spreading with astonishing rapidity and bringing turmoil to lives of those affected; say many men and women spend hours each week seeking sexual stimulation from their computers, masturbating to pornographic images or having 'mutual' online sex with someone contacted through chat room; say even when cybersex addicts and their partners seek treatment they often conceal real problem, and as result, diagnosis of cybersex addiction is often missed; drawing (M)
